After reviewing Senator Sessions’ decades-long record and participating in a thorough Judiciary Committee hearing, and after also hearing from many Delawareans, I have decided that I will vote against President-elect Trump’s nomination of Senator Sessions to serve as our nation’s next Attorney General.   I have served alongside Senator Sessions for six years, and during that time, we have worked together constructively on several criminal justice issues, including support for local law enforcement, reauthorization of the Victims of Child Abuse Act and restoration of funding to the Federal Public Defender Service.  On many more issues, however, including several that are core to my view of justice, Senator Sessions has vigorously opposed bipartisan reform efforts.   Any President deserves some latitude in picking nominees who support their principles, but on many important issues, including voting rights, civil rights, sentencing reform, LGBT rights, domestic violence protections, immigration reform, religious freedom, civil liberties, and torture, Senator Sessions has actively opposed bipartisan efforts to advance justice.  While I believe Senator Sessions will uphold the law, even those he disagrees with, the role of Attorney General is bigger than that.  I am concerned that Senator Sessions’ record as a prosecutor and an elected official demonstrates that on too many occasions he did not take action when there was an opportunity to stand up for the vulnerable, promote civil rights, or advance justice.    Today, the battle for equality continues in America, and our Attorney General cannot simply watch the march of history pass him by.  After carefully reviewing and considering his 30 years of public service, I do not believe that Sen. Sessions has taken sufficient action to demonstrate his commitment to lead the Department of Justice’s important work for all Americans.

I will not support President Trump’s nomination of Rex Tillerson to serve as our next Secretary of State.    I do not make this decision lightly, and Mr. Tillerson is someone I have grown to respect over the last few weeks through a public hearing and two private meetings. Mr. Tillerson is a thoughtful, seasoned professional whose impressive international business experience would serve him well in this important role. I have been encouraged by some of his public stances, including his clear-eyed understanding of the threat posed by Putin’s Russia, his commitment to the NATO alliance, his respect for U.S. leadership in multilateral initiatives, and his support for development programs throughout the world, especially in Africa.   Despite those strengths, Mr. Tillerson’s views also differ from mine in important ways. I believe that climate change is a pressing national security threat. I believe that advocating for human rights, a free press, and democracy around the world advances our own security and economic interests here at home.   I also believe that American leadership on the world stage is not as simple as President Trump’s slogan, ‘America First.’  If confirmed, it is my sincere hope that Mr. Tillerson will challenge President Trump to rethink his isolationist, dark view of the world and pursue a foreign policy that upholds American values. Should Mr. Tillerson be successful in moderating President Trump’s vision for America’s role in the world, I stand ready to work alongside him.

Nearly eighty years ago, in one of our country’s most shameful chapters, the United States refused entry to Jewish refugees fleeing the horrors of the Holocaust. Many of those denied refuge in the U.S. returned to Europe and were murdered by the Nazi regime. Today, Americans awoke to reports that refugees, many fleeing violence and persecution at home, have been detained at U.S. airports and are unable to enter the United States, even after years of waiting and thorough vetting. That the executive order by which we are denying them refuge was signed by President Trump on International Holocaust Remembrance Day displays a willful indifference to human suffering and to our own country’s history.  I understand the real fears that Americans have about bad actors seeking to take advantage of our compassion, but we cannot allow fears of terrorism to undermine the values that have made us an example for the rest of the world. The United States has in place thorough and detailed protocols to vet refugees seeking asylum. Instead of protecting us from terrorist attacks, the discriminatory standards for refugee admissions signed yesterday will more likely serve to fuel terrorist recruitment, further alienate Muslims in America, and force our allies in Europe to bear an even greater burden of refugee resettlement.  We are a nation of immigrants that has tried to lead by example. But today the world is seeing an America that is returning to a politics of exclusion based on religion or nationality. I’m angered and saddened by President Trump’s decision to sign an executive order that seems intended to make a point, not to make us safe. The executive orders by this president that exceed his authority can and should be challenged, as were the executive orders of previous presidents of both parties.

I’m pleased to announce that I joined with Senator Rob Portman (R-OH) to introduce a bipartisan bill focused on debt relief for grieving families. The Stop Taxing Death and Disability Act is rooted in the real experiences of folks around the country, constituents in my state, and even a member of my own staff. Eric Wall, a University of Delaware graduate working on my staff, had an older brother who developed a brain tumor and passed away just a year out of college. His brother had $75,000 in student loan debt, which his parents struggled to deal with as they grieved. Eric informed them that there is a federal program where you can get those loans forgiven in the case of permanent disability or death. They did so, only to be told they may have to pay thousands in taxes, because the IRS viewed it as imputed income. Our bill, which we introduced in the last Congress, would get rid of that burden on families grieving over death or disability.

President Trump’s withdrawal of federal guidance supporting protections for transgender students is arbitrary, misguided and cruel. This is not a states’ rights issue — it is a civil rights issue that affects students in every state across the country. It has long been settled that states must comply with federal civil rights laws, even when they disagree with particular applications of those laws. It is our obligation to protect the equal rights of American citizens, and President Trump’s withdrawal of guidance does not advance states’ rights – it legitimizes hate and discrimination. Fortunately, the Trump administration’s actions do not change our anti-discrimination laws under Title IX or the Constitution, which protect students of all gender identities. I am confident that these students’ rights will be vindicated in our courts, and I am proud to stand with them in this fight for justice.

Startups and small businesses are critical components of our innovation economy, accounting for substantial job growth each year. However, the sectors that these emerging entrepreneurs need to break into often necessitate a helping hand from us here in Washington. That’s why in 2015 I was proud to support bipartisan tax legislation that made the research and development (R&D) tax credit permanent and expanded it to help more small businesses and startups access it. The proposal to expand the credit was drawn from the Innovators Job Creation Act, a bill that I led along with Senator Pat Roberts and Congressmen Mike Kelly and Ron Kind.  But now that our proposal is law, it is our responsibility to make sure that research intensive startups in Delaware and around the country know how to claim the R&D credit. That’s why I teamed up again with Senator Roberts and Congressmen Kelly and Kind to reintroduce the Support Small Business R&D Act. This legislation will help startups capitalize on tax credits provided to incentivize businesses to take on research and development intensive projects.Our bill will accomplish this by requiring the Small Business Administration and Internal Revenue Service to develop educational and training materials for entrepreneurs who invest in research and could be qualified for the R&D tax credit. I will continue to strive to make sure that our startups and small businesses have the tools they need to take advantage of the R&D tax credit and continue to invest in advanced research.  https://www.coons.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/coons-roberts-kelly-kind-introduce-bipartisan-bicameral-bill-to-help-startups-and-small-businesses-invest-in-research

The images we saw earlier this week of Syrian children and adults who were brutally murdered and poisoned by their own government were not only heartbreaking and horrifying, they were a call to action for the global community.    While I’m encouraged that the Trump Administration has felt compelled to act forcefully in Syria against the Assad regime, I’m gravely concerned that the United States is engaging further militarily in Syria without a well-thought-out, comprehensive plan.  Frankly, the President’s actions today generate more questions than answers.   Chief among those questions is whether President Trump plans to work with Congress to address the ongoing crisis in Syria and to seek proper authorization for further use of military force.  I’ve called repeatedly on the Obama Administration and now the Trump Administration to stop Assad and end the humanitarian crisis in Syria, and in 2013, I voted to authorize former President Obama to use force to punish Assad for using chemical weapons against his own people.  Coordination and openness with Congress is more important than ever, and President Trump must seek an authorization for the use of military force from Congress, especially if this attack signals an intention to consider launching a campaign against Assad.   President Trump has steadily increased the number of American troops on the ground in Iraq and Syria engaged in the fight against ISIS.  This strike against Syria further complicates our engagement there.  Those troops, their families, and the American people deserve to know our plan for conducting, paying for, and concluding our involvement in this volatile region.

I’m deeply saddened by the passing of my friend and mentor, Eugene Lang. Gene was a visionary with a talent for persuading people to dream big and do more for others. A son of immigrants, Gene’s own improbable story of success in business and life began through a scholarship opportunity that allowed him to go to Swarthmore College, a gift he later paid forward many times over. With a sharp mind, a striking wit, and a tireless work ethic, Gene built a successful business licensing inventions and technology around the world before turning to his true calling: making a difference in the lives of others.    Gene’s extraordinary promise of a college scholarship to an entire class of middle school students from Harlem in 1981 was the stuff of legend. Gene went on to build the ‘I Have a Dream’ Foundation, a nationwide network of more than a hundred local chapters. The power of his vision and his passion for giving kids from tough schools and hard neighborhoods a genuine chance in life was infectious. My own life was changed by Gene from the moment I first met him in 1988. He inspired me to launch an ‘I Have a Dream’ Foundation chapter in my hometown of Wilmington, Delaware, and I later worked for Gene at the organization’s national office in New York and served on the national board for a decade. Through his demanding and inspiring leadership, Gene attracted an amazing constellation of supporters to his cause. I count among my closest friends the sponsors, staff, project coordinators, and Dreamers I met through him.   Gene’s vision of a country where an opportunity for higher education is available to all continues to motivate and inspire me, and so many more across our nation. I'll miss him greatly, and am thinking of his family during this difficult time.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/08/nyregion/eugene-lang-dead-harlem-college.html

Yesterday, I was honored to join Holocaust survivors Ania and Marcel Drimer in lighting candles in honor of the Holocaust Day of Remembrance.   Ania was born in a Soviet labor camp in 1942, where she faced severe conditions, including little food and sub-zero temperatures. Her mother, a lawyer, was the only woman in the camp, and her father, a physician, would barter medical care for food. It wasn’t until 1946 that the family was allowed to return to Poland. From there, Mrs. Drimer eventually moved to the United States to marry Marcel and work as a pharmacist.   Marcel was born in a small Polish town in May 1934. After the German Army invaded the territory in the summer of 1941, his family was forced into the Drohobycz ghetto. Before the ghetto was liquidated, his father bribed a guard so the family could escape the killing centers. A Ukrainian family hid them until they were liberated in August 1944. Malnourishment deprived Mr. Drimer of the use of his legs, but after relearning how to walk, he graduated from an engineering college and moved to the United States. Today, both Ania and Marcel volunteer regularly at the Holocaust Museum.   As we remember the horrors of the Holocaust and shine a light on the selfless acts countless individuals made to protect the lives of their Jewish neighbors, we must recommit: never again.

John McCain is a fighter, and I am hopeful he will once again beat the odds. During his naval service, John survived a terrible fire on board the USS Forrestal, he survived being shot down and he survived five and a half hard years of captivity. I have had the honor of serving with him and traveling with him repeatedly over the past seven years and he is a true leader and an American hero. I am praying for his full recovery and for the return of his forceful voice to the Senate.   Last month, I had the honor of traveling again with John McCain, this time to Vietnam and Singapore. We visited the site where his plane was shot down and the prison where he was a POW. Throughout our visit, I saw his humor and grace in recounting this very hard history, and in many meetings with senior Vietnamese officials, I saw the very high regard in which he is held throughout the country for his amazing work over 22 visits to Vietnam to reconcile our countries. We also visited the USS John McCain, named for his father and grandfather, in Cam Ranh Bay, where he spoke to the crew and presided over an inspiring re-enlistment and promotion ceremony. Finally, we visited Singapore for a regional security conference, where I heard across many meetings the deep respect for his leadership by many allies and adversaries alike across the region.  Overall, this trip was a chance to be reminded of Senator McCain's experience and leadership at a time when we need both in the Senate.  I truly hope he will return soon to continue his service in the Senate.

Today, I spoke at the Senate Human Rights Caucus event “Forced to Flee Burma: Stories of Rohingya Refugees in Bangladesh” with Senator Thom Tillis and experts from Refugees International, Human Rights Watch, the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, and the U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom. As a founder and Co-Chair of the Senate Human Rights Caucus, I believe strongly that support for human rights around the world is a value that every single one of us should understand and fight for. During my time in the Senate, I’ve had the opportunity to visit refugees around the world, most recently in Uganda. To look in the eyes of refugees, to witness them reaching a safe place after fleeing violence, is a powerful experience; it’s an experience that inspires me to continue fighting for humanitarian assistance abroad and funding to support refugees here in the United States.   In Burma, the country’s leaders have worked to advance peace after a historic 2015 election. However, as they try to achieve that broader peace, they must protect Internally Displaced Persons and find a path to citizenship for the Rohingya – a group that’s been denied citizenship since 1982, and has been suffering an unbelievable number of human rights violations at the hands of Burmese security forces. Since October 2016, over 70,000 people have fled Burma for Bangladesh. I am grateful to today’s panelists who offered recommendations for policymakers in Burma, Bangladesh, and the United States to address the protection of the Rohingya.

Today, Senator Tom Carper and I, along with 43 of our Democratic colleagues, sent a letter to President Trump and GOP leaders expressing our desire to work together to modernize our tax system. We also laid out three important principles for those negotiations. First, we believe that tax reform should not increase the tax burden on the middle class. This includes our belief that we should not give tax cuts to the top 1% and special interest groups. I am deeply disappointed by the President’s decision today to end the DACA program. Since 2012, DACA has allowed immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children to defer removal and apply for work visas.  DACA has helped over 750,000 DREAMers work, study and contribute to our society free of the constant fear of being forced to leave the only home they have ever known. Those who come to our country as children, without authorization but through no fault of their own, deserve the opportunity to live their lives out of the shadows. Not only will ending DACA hurt the thousands of immigrant families whose loved ones may be forced to leave the United States, but I believe our federal immigration enforcement resources are much better focused on those who are actively a threat to our community.  DREAMers are overwhelmingly hard working and tax paying, many have served in our armed forces or graduated near the top of their schools and should be allowed to continue to contribute to our nation. President Trump has gone back on his promise to 'treat DACA with heart,' and Congress now has the urgent responsibility to fix our broken immigration system in a bipartisan way that protects DREAMers.  I was proud to be an active part of the legislative process that delivered bipartisan immigration reform that passed the Senate in 2013, and I intend to work hard to do so again. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/05/us/politics/trump-daca-dreamers-immigration.html?smid=tw-nytpolitics&smtyp=cur

Each year, 8 million metric tons of plastic enter the ocean. It is estimated that the ocean may already contain upward of 150 million metric tons. This garbage wreaks havoc on our oceans, harming fish and ocean wildlife, and important habitats like coral reef. This is a global problem: we’re all a cause and we must all work towards a solution.   Last month, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado and I had the opportunity to visit West Africa.  While there, we met with government leaders to ask what we, as representatives of the American people, can do to help as African nations work to create the first ever African Marine Waste Action Plan.  For the first time, dozens of African nations are coming together to discuss what they can do to stem the tide of marine debris.   Here at home, you can do your part by joining a river or beach cleanup near you. In the Senate, we will continue to support solutions that prevent trash from getting into the ocean.  This weekend is the world’s biggest volunteer effort to protect the ocean: the International Coastal Cleanup.  If you love the ocean and want to protect it, find a cleanup near you and get involved!

President Trump’s rule threatens the guarantee of contraceptive coverage for the 62 million women across the country currently covered by allowing for-profit employers to end coverage of birth control for their employers to end coverage of birth control for their employees based on a religious or moral objection without requiring a way for women to get that coverage. A woman’s choice in birth control should be between her and her doctor, and the religious beliefs of the woman’s boss should have no role in it. This is another attempt at discrimination against women, particularly those who lack the financial means to pay for contraceptive care out of pocket. A woman’s boss should not be allowed to decide which forms of birth control and other health services she can access and I’m proud to support legislation that would prevent them from doing so. http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/356202-dems-release-bill-to-block-trump-birth-control-rule

I'm deeply concerned about a provision in the House GOP tax bill to tax tuition waivers for graduate students and employees at universities. Taxing these waivers will make graduate school unaffordable for many promising American students! I've heard from several graduate students in Delaware about how these waivers allow them to attend school and, if these waivers were taxed, they would be forced to leave. We should be helping these students who are our future inventors, leaders, and entrepreneurs. But, don't just take it from me, take it from these UD graduate students who rely on this exemption:   “My husband and I are both in the PhD program here at UD, I am on a fellowship, he is a research assistant. We have both served as teaching assistants and research assistants in our time here. Each of us has a stipend of ~$20k, which seems like a lot, but housing in Newark is expensive and we have a 3-year-old whose dependent health insurance premiums are now over $3500 each year. When you add up the cost of living alone, plus PART-TIME daycare (3 half days a week so I can actually get a little work done), we have less than $750 a month left to eat, buy diapers, feed the dog, pay for emergencies, etc. This still seems like a lot, but it goes fast. AND because we don't get paid over the summer, I am expected to squirrel away enough money for us to live over the summer when we aren't on contract, too?! We break even at tax time every year - we always end up having to pay the state of Delaware, but our federal return usually is just enough to cover it. Grad school is hard. Grad school for two, with a kid, is even more difficult. Even a tiny increase in our taxable income would create not only financial pressure, but mental and emotional stress that myself, and many other grad students, would not be able to handle. I'm lucky, I think I will finish before this tax plan would go into effect, but what about all the other grad students in the exact same situation who would honestly have to choose between finishing a PhD and feeding their kid?! It's infuriating.” – J.H., University of Delaware   “I chose the Physical Ocean Science and Engineering PhD program and the University of Delaware because I felt the need to help stop climate change and be a part of the movement towards renewable energy, but this tax bill could force me to leave school. My personal stipend is $27,900. The proposed tax on our tuition waivers would end up costing me personally around an addition $6,000 in taxes a year, which will be more than 20% of my actual income. Most graduate students already work for close to minimum wage; this proposed burden to our finances will make graduate school only attainable for the independently wealthy. If this tax reform goes through, I believe many people will stop entering graduate school which will equate to a breakdown in the higher education system. With no students to do graduate work, professors’ research work will greatly slow, and without students graduating, the supply of qualified people for jobs requiring higher education will diminish. I personally do not know if I’ll be able to afford graduate school if this tax bill goes through. I’ve been financially independent from my parents for 4 years, so I if I suddenly cannot afford to pay rent and buy groceries I’m not sure what I'll be able to do, other than to abandon my goal of getting an advanced degree" - Gwendolyn, University of Delaware   “I'm a PhD candidate in the Materials Science and Engineering department at the University of Delaware and my current stipend is close to $30,000/year. My tuition the first two years of graduate school was close to $28,000/year. My combined federal and state income taxes would jump from $3,530/year to $10,188/year, a ridiculous tax amount for income that I do not even make. My income before taxes would be the same in each case: $30,000/year. But my income after taxes would be $6,658/year less under this new plan. Unless I'm misunderstanding the bill, this makes no sense to me. This additional tax burden would severely degrade the quality of graduate research by reducing the number of qualified students and increasing the financial stress--and likely affecting the mental health--of students who choose to follow this career path, especially in the first two years when waived tuition is the highest.” - Eric Chen, University of Delaware   “I'm a PhD student in Water Science and Policy and I just moved out to Delaware with my partner from New Mexico. He teaches as an adjunct at UD and at DTCC, so he doesn't receive benefits. Paying for his health insurance, our apartment, any remaining tuition fees, and all of our other expenses means that we basically break even every month. He's also applying to a PhD program starting in Fall 2018. If we were both students and had to pay additional taxes on the tuition that the University isn't charging us, we wouldn't be able to afford to be here. We've both been in debt to colleges before and have agreed that we won't do so again, especially not in graduate school. Going for a PhD means sacrificing valuable work experience for higher education and the advancement of knowledge. We already donate much of our time to our classes or working as TAs or RAs. Asking us to go pay taxes as if we were middle-income earners working 40 hour a week jobs is less than fair and would represent a dark time for graduate education in this country" - Aaron Russell, University of Delaware  #SaveGradEd

Throughout the past months, I've urged my Republican colleagues to work across the aisle on a bipartisan tax reform bill that Senators from both parties could get behind. Last week, I joined more than a dozen Democratic Senators to ask our Republican colleagues to slow this process down and work together.   Finally, over the last few days, I've been working with a handful of my Republican and Democratic colleagues to try to find a way - any way - to stop this backroom, partisan process and force both parties to work together on tax reform. We got close to an agreement, but ultimately didn't succeed.   The bill that appears likely to pass the Senate soon is a bad one. There's no sugar coating it. This bill gives away tens of billions in corporate tax cuts with no strings attached, hurts the middle class over the long run, guts the Affordable Care Act, and adds more than $1 trillion to the national debt. It was written with no meaningful consultation between the two parties, and it is highly unpopular with the American public.    This process isn't finished yet, as the Senate and House bills remain very different, but I am very concerned that we're close to making our already-broken tax code even worse. As always, I remain willing to work across the aisle to pass a real, bipartisan tax reform bill for the middle class, but our opportunity to do that is quickly slipping away.
